module.p: lunn is a masculine common noun, with genitive singular forms luinn or lunna, and plural form lunnan. It is sometimes found with o rather than u – lonn, loinn, lonna, lonnan.

There appear to be two main dictionary senses of the noun lunn (MacBain, Dwelly) –
large wave, heaving billow, heaver, roller – derived from the adjective lonn strong, powerful, fierce, itself from the Old Gaelic lonn fierce, strong, violent, vehement, eager, bold; irascible, angry
timber put under a boat for launching it, roller, derived from Old Norse hlunnr, a roller for launching ships
[by extension] the middle, round part of an oar handle, staff, lever, bar

When followed by an infinitive (verbal noun), air lunn can also be used to mark prospective aspect about to, on the verge/point of, though mainly in older texts –
Tha iad air lunn a dhol ann. They are on the verge/point of going.

Examples –
air lunn a dhol –
air lonn a dhol dhachaidh
on the point of going home td. 599
Tha mi gle thoilichte ’chluinntinn gu bheil m’ fhear-cinnidh agus mo charaid Aonghas Caimbeil còir fathast beò slan. Bha toil mhor agam o chionn bhliadhnaichean dol g’ a fhaicinn. Ach ged tha mi air chuairt ghoirid an Ceap Breatuinn, cha mhor gach bliadhna, cha do cheadaich ùine dhomh sin a dheanamh. B’ fhear leam gu ’m b’ urrainn dhomh latha ’chur seachad maille ris air an t-samhradh ’s a tighinn; agus co aige tha fhios, ma bhios e-fhein ’s mi-fhein air caomhnadh beo, nach faodadh gu ’n tachradh sin. “Coinnichidh na daoine ’s cha choinnich na cnuic.” Cha ’n ann a h-uile latha bhios cothrom aig neach a nis air aon fhaicinn a rugadh anns an ochdamh linn deug. Bu ghle thoigh leam cuid de nithe, tha air lunn dol air di-chuimhne, fhaotainn a mach bho Aonghas Caimbeul.
I am very happy to hear that my clansman and my dear friend Angus Campbell is still alive and kicking. I had the great pleasure of going to see him years ago. But even though I was on a short trip in Cape Breton, almost every year, time did not allow me to do that. I would prefer to be able to spend a day with him this coming summer; and who knows, if he and I are still alive, that might still happen. “Men will meet and hills will not meet.” It is not every day that a person has the opportunity now to see someone who was born in the eighteenth century. I would very much like to find out some things, that are about to be forgotten, from Angus Campbell. Vol. 6 td. 332 rach air dìochuimhne become forgotten
’An ùine nach robh fada, ’n uair a bha na gillean a bha ’fàireachas air cùl a’ chnuic a’ faicinn gu ’n robh an càirdean féin a’ gleidheadh an gruinnd gu maith, ’s gu ’n robh an là air lunn a dhol leò, bhruchd iad a nuas le leathad a’ chnuic ’n an aon mheall, gun rian, gun òrdugh, ’s ni eigin de atharrais armachd – cabar no ni sam bith air am faigheadh e greim aig gach fear air a ghualainn, no na láimh.

Ach is e a rinn e, – thill e air ais a rithisd far an robh Mac Mhic Raonuill, agus thachair e ris anns an àite cheudna far an d’fhàg e e, agus e ’na chadal; agus bha e ag éigheachd ris gu a dhùsgadh gus an d’ fhairtlich air a dhùsgadh. Dh’fhalbh e agus rug e air làimh air, agus gu de rinn an làmh ach tighinn as a’ ghuallainn, agus leum an fhuil ’na spùt mu a shùilean. An uair a chunnaic esan gu ’n robh an duine uasal urramach so air lunn a bhi seachad, shìn e a mach anns a’ chaoineadh ’s anns an rànaich.
But what he did is – he went back again to where the Son of the Son of Ronald was and he encountered him in the very same place where he had left him, asleep; and he was shouting at him to wake up until he failed to wake him up. He left and he grabbed him by the arm, and what did the arm do but come away from the shoulder, and the blood jumped spouting around his eyes. When he saw that the venerable nobleman was about to die, he lay down bawling and crying. td. 88
Bha aon mhac eil’ aig an rìgh air an robh Seumas, an ceud fhear de na Seumasan. ’S e smuainich e féin ’s a’ bhan-righ air an òganach a chur air falbh gu cuirt rìgh na Frainge, far am faigheadh e iunnsachadh iomchuidh do ’n inbh’ àird ’s an robh e, agus ’am biodh e tearuint’ o ais-innleachdaibh bhràthair-athar. Rinn iad ullachadh air son a chur air falbh co cabhagach, ’s co uaigneach ’s a ghabhadh deanamh; ach mu ’n d’ fhuair an soitheach a bha gus am prionns’ a ghiùlan fo sheòl ’s fo astar, thuig Albani an rud a bh’ ann, ’s gu ’n robh ’n t-eun air lunn a bhi gu sgiobalt’ a mach as a lìon féin. Ach an aon ni a ghabhadh deanamh a nis rinn se e gu cabhagach; ghrad chuir e teachdaire ’thoirt sanas do righ Shasuinn. ’N uair a ràinig an soitheach ’s an robh am prionns’ oirthir Norfoc, bha càbhlach beag Sasunnach a’ feitheamh oirre.
The king had another son called James, the first of the Jameses. He and the queen thought to send the boy away to the court of the king of France, where he would get appropriate learning for the high status he was in, and where he would be safe from his uncle’s machinations. They made preparations to send him away so hurriedly, and so secretly as it was possible to do; but before the ship that was about to carry the prince got under sail and underway, Albany [ie. his uncle] realised what was happening, and that the bird was soon about to be out of his net. But the one thing that was possible now he did hurriedly; speedily he sent a messenger to inform the king of England. When the ship which the prince was in reached the coast of Norfolk, a small English fleet was waiting for it. td. 134
Thuig Seumas an sin nach robh e tearuinnte dha ’aghaidh a chur gu tuath. An déigh do ’n rìgh òrdugh a thoirt do ’n bheagan airm a lean ris iad a sgaoileadh, dh’fhan Cleabhars far an robh e car greis. ’N uair a chunnaic e Uilleam air lunn a bhi air a dheanamh ’na righ, dh’fhàg e ’n t-arm, ’s ruith e dhachaidh le deich marcaich fhichead mar geard, a’ rùnachadh gu ’n deanadh e na b’ urrainn e ’n Alba gus am bacadh o rìgh Uilleam a roghnuchadh.
James realised then that it was not safe for him to head north. After the king had given an order to the little army that followed him to scatter them, Claverhouse waited where he was for a while. When he saw William about to be made king, he left the army, and he ran home with thirty horsemen as a guard, intending to do what he could in Scotland to prevent them from choosing William as king. td. 328

Ri linn Dhònuill, mar is minig a bh’ ann bho sin, bha ùdlaiche ainmeil a’ tathaich Gual’-an-liathghiuthais, agus là ’bha ’sin smaoinich e gu ’n tugadh e sgrib a null a ghabhail fàth air. Togar air ma ta thair an Uisge-dhubh; ach mar a bha an rosad ’an dàn, co ’bha an latha sin ’s a’ bheinn-sheilg ach “Dunnachadh Dubh a’ Churraic” agus a ghillean air an t-slighe chiadna, agus mu ’n d’ fhairich Dònull thall no bhos e, bha e ’an’ sàs aca. Cha robh comas air – b’ éudar glacadh a ghabhail, agus falbh leotha do Fhionnlairig. Chaidh ainm Dhònuill fada ’s goirid, agus le farmad-cùirte bha na gillean air lunn cur as da, ach bu bhàrd an Ridire e fhéin, ’s cha leigeadh e leotha làmh a chur ann.
In Donald’s time, as it has often been since then, a famous stag was frequenting Grey Pine Shoulder, and one day he thought that he would take a trip over to catch a glimpse of it. He went then over the Black Water; but as if the misfortune was destined, who was on the hunting mountain that day but “Black Duncan of the Cap” and his boys on the very same path, and before Donald was aware of it, he was in their grasp. It couldn’t be helped – he had to be taken prisoner and leave with them for Fionn Lairig. Donald’s name went long and short, and [with envy of court?] the boys were about to get rid of him, but he himself was the Knight’s poet, and he wouldn’t let them put a hand on him. Vol. 5 td. 329
